author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Finally, an Inclusive Range of Gowns for Brides of Color
description: “Nude” fabrics and undergarments are often beige or white. More bridal designers of color are trying to change that.
content: In January, Tessa Tookes tried on her dream wedding dress at a bridal boutique in Ontario. When the store employees told her she would have to pay $200 for the bra cups of the gown to match her skin color, her heart sank. The beige cups that had already been built into the dress, however, were free. Ivory cups were also a free option.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk
title: Crowdfunding, Auctions and Raffles: How Ukrainians Are Aiding the Army
description: Fund-raisers are borrowing heavily from business techniques to keep donations flowing to the military. The latest trend? Broad approaches that rely on networks of friends and acquaintances.
content: Earlier this year, Daria Chervona, a photo retoucher from Kyiv, was busy trying to raise 78 million Ukrainian hryvnia, about $2 million, for Ukraine’s army, posting daily on social media to urge friends and acquaintances to chip in. That was a high bar, but after a few weeks she announced she had cleared it, reaching her target.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Tripp Mickle and Cade Metz
title: Key OpenAI Executive Played a Pivotal Role in Sam Altman’s Ouster
description: Mira Murati, OpenAI’s chief technology officer, brought questions about Mr. Altman’s management to the board last year before he was briefly ousted from the company, people familiar with the matter said.
content: More than three months after OpenAI’s board of directors briefly ousted Sam Altman, the chief executive of the high-profile artificial intelligence company, questions remain about exactly what led the board to make such a dramatic move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: City Inquiry: Uvalde Officers Made Mistakes, but Did Not Violate Policy
description: An investigator for the city of Uvalde found that despite the many failures from police officers during a 2022 school shooting, they did not violate protocol and acted in good faith.
content: An investigator for the city of Uvalde said on Thursday that despite the many documented failures of more than 20 city police officers who were among those responding to the shooting at Robb Elementary School in 2022, no punishment was warranted because the officers acted in good faith and did not violate department policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Not Just for Scooby-Doo Anymore — the Secret Door Is Having a Moment
description: Homeowners are adding hidden doors and rooms to foil burglars, eke out extra storage space and prepare for Armageddon.
content: Tabitha Kane is a co-host of a true crime podcast so it might not come as a complete surprise to learn that when she and her husband were planning a new house for their family in Dallas, she cooked up the idea of adding a secret room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: A Gentle Nightmare (Paging Dr. Freud)
description: Pontus Lidberg’s “On the Nature of Rabbits” at the Joyce Theater is a dance haunted by AIDS.
content: As a title for a dance, “On the Nature of Rabbits” is unusual. So is the presence of a dancer wearing an oversized rabbit head. That might be comic or creepy. In this work, by the Swedish choreographer Pontus Lidberg, rabbits are part of a nightmare, and an awfully Freudian one. The rabbit is comfort, desire and death, as well as a psychological block that undermines adult relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: The Case Trump Really Hates
description: Prosecutors want to present steamy details at the hush money trial.
content: For the past couple of weeks, the spotlight has been focused on the timing of Donald Trump’s four criminal trials and the prospect that at least two of them might not go to a jury before this fall’s election. And the one trial that seems certain to be held before Election Day — his so-called hush money case — has often been dismissed by experts and observers as old, legally dubious and lacking in the sort of weighty issues that sit at the heart of, say, his two election interference cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Histories of the American West and Southeast Asian Wars Win Bancroft Prize
description: The award, one of the most distinguished in the field of American history, honors “scope, significance, depth of research and richness of interpretation.”
content: A sweeping history of 19th-century westward expansion and an unflinching study of Richard Nixon, Henry Kissinger and the wars in Southeast Asia have won this year’s Bancroft Prize, considered one of the most prestigious honors in the field of American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain Is Cutting Taxes Again. Why Now?
description: The government announced a budget as a national election looms. Here’s what you need to know.
content: At least once a year, Britain’s top financial official stands up in Parliament to lay out his — it has always been a his to date — tax and spending plans that are normally intended to bolster economic growth and keep a check on the nation’s debt. This year, Jeremy Hunt, the chancellor of the Exchequer, had to consider another priority: the upcoming general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Rivian Will Delay Construction of a $5 Billion Factory in Georgia
description: The money-losing electric vehicle company, which makes vans, trucks and S.U.V.s, is trying to preserve cash as it works to produce and sell more affordable vehicles.
content: Rivian, a young electric vehicle company, said on Thursday that it was halting construction of a new factory in Georgia. The company also announced two new models, one of which will now be produced at its plant in Illinois.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Democrats Invite Reproductive Rights Advocates, Putting Abortion and I.V.F. in the Spotlight
description: Democrats are contrasting their support for reproductive rights with Republicans’ records of opposing protections for abortion and fertility treatments.
content: Among the hundreds of guests who will fill the House chamber on Thursday evening — each invited to telegraph distinct political messages — will be dozens of reproductive rights advocates and providers invited by Democrats who are looking to put access to abortion and fertility treatments front and center this election year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: When Teens Visit Doctors, Increasingly the Subject is Mental Health
description: A new study provides further evidence of the challenges that adolescents and young adults face.
content: Increasingly, doctor visits by adolescents and young adults involve mental health diagnoses, along with the prescription of psychiatric medications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Who Are the Gangs That Have Overrun Haiti’s Capital?
description: The Caribbean nation has plunged into disorder and violence with gangs controlling access to the main airport and seaports, and taking command of many parts of Port-au-Prince.
content: Haiti, a Caribbean nation with a long history of upheaval, is enduring one of its worst periods of chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Sweden Enters NATO, a Blow to Moscow and a Boost to the Baltic Nations
description: With the addition of Sweden to NATO, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia finds himself facing an enlarged and motivated alliance.
content: Sweden formally joined NATO on Thursday, becoming its 32nd member two years after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and sharply bolstering, with Finland, the military alliance’s deterrent in the Baltic and North Seas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Oscars 2024 Predictions: Who Will Win Best Picture, Actor and Actress?
description: “Oppenheimer” is the best picture favorite, but the best actress race is full of suspense. Our expert predicts which films and artists will get trophies on Sunday.
content: Let’s be real: The best picture race is locked up for “Oppenheimer.” Christopher Nolan gave Oscar voters an IMAX-sized helping of their favorite genre — the great-man-of-history biopic — and after the movie made nearly a billion dollars worldwide, its path to the top Oscar was clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Alabama Passes Law to Protect I.V.F. Treatments
description: Two major fertility clinics said they were moving to resume treatments quickly, though legal experts cautioned that state constitutional challenges may still arise.
content: Alabama lawmakers passed legislation on Wednesday to shield in vitro fertilization providers from civil and criminal liability, capping off their scramble to allow the fertility treatment after a State Supreme Court ruling found that frozen embryos should be considered children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Tree Stump
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Gelinas and Gus Aronson
title: The Disappearance of Mayor Adams
description: Unlike most of his predecessors, he has had few accomplishments while leading New York City. But there’s still time to change that.
content: Halfway through Eric Adams’s term as mayor of New York, many of the headlines he generates aren’t about the city; they’re about his personal problems. The F.B.I. raided the home of his chief campaign fund-raiser. Agents seized his cellphones and iPad. Government officials are looking into whether he received illegal campaign donations from foreigners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Self-Service for Airport Security? It’s Happening in Las Vegas.
description: At security lanes at Harry Reid International Airport, travelers with PreCheck clearance can test a new self-service screening process with remote T.S.A. agents and video monitors.
content: As most air travelers can attest, the experience at an airport’s security checkpoint can be far from serene. There are many rules — often shouted by Transportation Security Administration officers — about what you can bring with you, how to array your belongings and where to stand. Lines can be painfully long and anxieties sky high. And throughout the process, there are security officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: How China Came to Dominate the World in Solar Energy
description: Beijing is set to further increase its manufacturing and installation of solar panels as it seeks to master global markets and wean itself from imports.
content: China unleashed the full might of its solar energy industry last year. It installed more solar panels than the United States has in its history. It cut the wholesale price of panels it sells by nearly half. And its exports of fully assembled solar panels climbed 38 percent while its exports of key components almost doubled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: National Guard in the Subway? New Yorkers Have Their Doubts.
description: Some commuters said they felt safer after learning that heavily armed soldiers would patrol the subway system. Others were critical of the governor’s plan.
content: The day after Gov. Kathy Hochul announced a plan to deploy National Guard soldiers and State Police troopers in the New York City subway system, commuters expressed mixed feelings about whether the extra vigilance would make them feel any safer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | March 13, 2024
description: What do some fourth graders think are humanity’s biggest problems? Do they think adults are doing a good job of running the world?
content: These graphs were previously published in The New York Times for Kids, a monthly print-only section that helps young readers understand the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Urges Recall of Cinnamon Brands Tainted by Lead
description: The agency tested 75 types of cinnamon after hundreds of children were poisoned by the spice in applesauce. It found some lead in cinnamon brands sold at some dollar stores and other markets.
content: The Food and Drug Administration is telling consumers to throw out certain brands of cinnamon that were found to have elevated levels of lead, and it urged companies to recall the products from store shelves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Mutual Frustrations Arise in U.S.-Ukraine Alliance
description: Ukrainian officials are disheartened about stalled aid. The Pentagon wants Kyiv to heed its advice on how to fight.
content: More than two years into their wartime alliance, the bond between the United States and Ukraine is showing signs of wear and tear, giving way to mutual frustration and a feeling that the relationship might be stuck in a bit of a rut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Don’t Let Daylight Saving Time Ruin Your Sleep
description: Here’s how to feel well rested when the clocks spring forward on Sunday.
content: Daffodils are blooming, temperatures are rising, days are lengthening — all sure signs of spring. But another, less welcome change is afoot: At 2 a.m. on Sunday, most people in the United States will “spring” their clocks forward by one hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg
title: Yep, He Did It Again
description: The media titan Rupert Murdoch, 92, is engaged once more. This time it is to Elena Zhukova, a retired molecular biologist.
content: Rupert Murdoch decided that at 92, it was time to give up the reins of power at his media empire — but it seems he believes age is no barrier for new love, or a new marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Word of the Day: scrupulous

content: The word scrupulous has appeared in 36 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 21 in “An HGTV Star’s Party Inspires a Question: What Makes a Home?” by Melissa Kirsch:

title: Chelsea Hotel’s Cast of Characters, Captured by Its Resident Photographer
description: Plus: a chef’s guesthouse in Bali, art that explores girlhood — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: In the morning I tend to wash my face before I get in the shower. I usually use the Dr. Barbara Sturm Enzyme Cleanser; it’s lightweight so is great for travel and comes in a powder form you mix with water. I’m a longtime user of Biologique Recherche and swear by Lotion P50. On my eyes I use the Tata Harper Elixir Vitae Eye Serum, which is firming and lifting. My moisturizer depends on the season: When it’s cold I’ll use Augustinus Bader the Cream. If it’s humid I’ll use the Light Cream. About a year ago, I discovered this desert island product, which is Natura Bissé Diamond Cocoon Sheer Eye cream — it’s a tinted eye cream that makes you look rested. After the shower, I use the Augustinus Bader Body Lotion. When I need it, I’ll use either Biologique Recherche Masque Vernix, which is a bit rich, or Auteur’s retinol serum. For flights, I always take the Omorovicza Queen of Hungary Evening Mist with me — the flight attendants will usually ask for a spray. Sisley has this Black Rose Cream Mask that’s always in my travel bag, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sofia Quaglia
title: Bizarre, Wormlike and Oozing Milk for Their Babies
description: Amphibians called caecilians add cloacal secretions of a nutritious material similar to milk to their numerous quirks, according to a new study.
content: Motherhood takes many shapes. Most vertebrates, like birds, reptiles, amphibians and fish, reproduce by laying eggs filled with nourishing yolk that their offspring use as an initial source of nutrition before hatching. Mammals change the game by giving birth to live young and feeding them fatty, sugary milk as they get on their feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Hamas Negotiators Leave Cairo With No Breakthrough in Cease-Fire Talks
description: Weeks of indirect negotiations appear to have stalled over Hamas’s insistence on a permanent cease-fire during or after any hostage releases, a demand that Israel has rejected.
content: Hamas negotiators left Cairo on Thursday without a breakthrough in talks over a cease-fire in Gaza, the group said, as hopes for an imminent truce in its five-month-long war with Israel continued to dim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Man Who Became Champion of Rehabilitation Is Charged With Murder
description: Sheldon Johnson became a youth worker with the Queens Defenders after his release from prison last year.
content: Since his release from prison last May, Sheldon Johnson had become a public face of rehabilitation and even redemption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: A Chicken Stew With Mayan Roots
description: The modern version of jocón incorporates Mayan techniques and ingredients, as well as Spanish components.
content: Seven years ago, just as Jorge Cárdenas was about to open Ix Restaurant in Prospect Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, he returned to his home in Quetzaltenango, in the highlands of Guatemala, to make sure that his recipes tasted like those his Mayan grandmother had taught him to make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: War in Gaza Presents Biden With Challenges at Home and Abroad
description: Domestic and international anger over Israel’s response to the Oct. 7 attacks has complicated President Biden’s diplomatic and re-election efforts.
content: Nearly five months since Hamas militants attacked and killed about 1,200 people in Israel, President Biden has been swept into the resulting upheaval in the region. As he prepares to address the nation, he finds himself navigating a wider Middle East emergency with profound moral, political and security implications for his presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: A Subway Plan Aimed to Ease Fears. The Blowback Was Immediate.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s subway safety plan was meant to show how Democrats can take action on crime, but the response illustrated how the issue divides her party.
content: Just 24 hours after Gov. Kathy Hochul deployed the National Guard and the State Police in the New York City subway to quell fears of crime, the unusual show of force drew intense criticism on Thursday from various corners, some unexpected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: State Investigations Create More Peril for Trump Prosecutor in Georgia
description: A claim made about the prosecutor, Fani Willis, at a State Senate hearing proved false, but it hinted at the turbulence she might face even if an effort to disqualify her fails.
content: A new investigation unfolding at the Georgia State Capitol is previewing the turbulence that Fani T. Willis, the district attorney prosecuting Donald J. Trump, may face even if a judge allows her to keep the high-stakes case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Southeast on Edge as Forecast Threatens More Rain
description: Soppy soil is creating a concern for more flooding in the South and the Northeast after recent rains.
content: The sky was blue over Atlanta on Thursday morning, but the ground made a squishing sound if you walked across it, soaked from heavy rains the day before that left streets muddy with red Georgia clay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alana Pockros
title: Nona Faustine: She’s Putting Herself in Their Places
description: In striking self-portraits at the Brooklyn Museum, the artist revisits locations with histories of enslavement and reimagines the body as a site of power.
content: It makes perfect sense that Nona Faustine’s introduction to professional photography was through photojournalism. While her photographs are always premeditated and posed, their primary intent is to calcify a particular moment in time to ensure that she — and we — never forget it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Kate Christobek
title: Judge’s Order Will Prevent Trump From Revealing Names of Jurors
description: Donald J. Trump’s legal team agreed with the restrictions regarding his hush-money trial. The judge also ruled that only the lawyers in the case will know the jurors’ addresses.
content: A New York judge on Thursday effectively barred former President Donald J. Trump from exposing the identities of potential jurors at his first criminal trial later this month, emphasizing a need to protect those who might decide the highly sensitive case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Elisa Gutierrez and Caitlin O'Keefe
title: Why It Had to Be Biden
description: According to the Democratic National Committee and Biden’s inner circle, he is the best option in a battle with Trump, no matter what voters might be worried about.
content: With Super Tuesday behind us, this week is the end of one chapter of this campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Lisa Friedman
title: State of the Union Guests Highlight Biden’s Efforts on Gun Violence, the Climate and More
description: The White House’s invited guests included the sister of a 9-year-old girl killed in the Uvalde school shooting, the head of the U.A.W. and business owners focused on the environment.
content: The White House guest list for President Biden’s State of the Union address underscored some of his administration’s biggest accomplishments, from student debt forgiveness to the expansion of NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: How Much Exercise Do You Get Each Week?
description: Are you satisfied with the amount of physical activity you do?
content: Is fitness an important part of your life? Are you the type of person who works out every day? Or do you find exercise intimidating, overwhelming or just plain boring?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: The ‘Rule’ Against Ending Sentences With Prepositions Has Always Been Silly
description: Where does the ‘rule’ come from? Latin. Why do we do it anyway? Vikings.
content: Late last month, Merriam-Webster shared the news on Instagram that it’s OK to end a sentence with a preposition. Hats off to them, sincerely. But it is hard to convey how bizarre, to an almost comical degree, such a decree seems in terms of how language actually works. It is rather like announcing that it is now permissible for cats to meow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: Canadian Jailed by China in Tit-for-Tat Dispute Gets a Settlement
description: Michael Spavor, a Canadian businessman, was arrested by China in what his lawyers said was an act of retaliation for Canada’s detention of a Chinese tech giant executive.
content: The government of Canada has reached a financial settlement with one of two Canadian men it contends were arbitrarily detained for nearly three years by China in a retaliatory move, the man’s lawyer said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Say Trump’s Secret Files Case ‘Starkly Different’ from Biden’s
description: The special counsel, Jack Smith, filed an array of rebuttals to motions by former President Donald J. Trump to dismiss his documents case.
content: Prosecutors in former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case sought on Thursday to rebut his claim that he is a victim of selective prosecution, rejecting the former president’s argument that he was being treated more harshly than President Biden had been in an investigation into his handling of sensitive materials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: How a Sudden Halt to In Vitro Fertilization Shook Alabama Couples
description: Many suffered setbacks after the State Supreme Court ruled that frozen embryos were children. “Someone else’s opinion changed my future,” one woman said.
content: Leelee Ray and her husband, Austin, have been trying to have a baby for six years, through insemination procedures, two egg retrievals, four embryo transfers, an ectopic pregnancy that could have been deadly and eight miscarriages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Lynn Levy, Diane Wong and Manohla Dargis
title: The Oscar-Nominated Documentary That Made My Heart Race
description: Our critic on the experience of watching “20 Days in Mariupol.”
content: The Ukrainian journalist Mstyslav Chernov was in Mariupol, in the southeastern part of the country, when the Russian invasion began. The footage that he and his colleagues gathered there became “20 Days in Mariupol,” one of this year’s Oscar nominees for best documentary feature. Our critic Manohla Dargis talks about the impact the film had on her, and how Chernov’s filmmaking “closes the distance between you and what you are watching.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and J. David Goodman
title: State Investigators Say Power Lines Ignited Record Texas Fire
description: The conclusion came as a utility company said its facilities in the Texas Panhandle “appear to have been involved in an ignition” of the fire, which has burned more than one million acres.
content: State investigators concluded that the largest wildfire on record in Texas history was “ignited by power lines,” a spokeswoman for the Texas A&M Forest Service, which conducted the inquiry, said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: Spate of Mock News Sites With Russian Ties Pop Up in U.S.
description: The fake news organizations, experts say, represent a technological leap in the Kremlin’s efforts to spread false and misleading narratives.
content: Into the depleted field of journalism in America, a handful of websites have appeared in recent weeks with names suggesting a focus on news close to home: D.C. Weekly, the New York News Daily, the Chicago Chronicle and a newer sister publication, the Miami Chronicle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Embryo Transfers Resume in Alabama, Even as Legal Questions Remain
description: Hours after the governor signed a law that offers legal protections to clinics and doctors performing I.V.F. procedures, at least one clinic resumed embryo transfers.
content: At least one Alabama fertility clinic resumed embryo transfers on Thursday, just hours after Gov. Kay Ivey signed a law that offered clinics and doctors legal protection for in vitro fertilization procedures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Six Key Questions Ahead of Biden’s State of the Union
description: What campaign themes will he lay out? How directly will he attack Donald Trump? Will he say the word abortion?
content: Follow live updates on Biden’s State of the Union address.

author: By Troy Closson
title: 8-Year-Old Carried a Gun Into a New York City School, Police Say
description: The gun was unloaded, and no students were injured, according to the Police Department.
content: An 8-year-old boy in Brooklyn carried a gun to school on Thursday, according to the authorities, who said police officers found it after searching his backpack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: What Is Your Earliest Pandemic Memory?
description: As the fourth anniversary of the Covid lockdowns approaches, we’re collecting stories of the moments readers’ worlds shut down.
content: Remembering life in the earliest days of the pandemic shutdowns can feel like trying to conjure an apocalyptic dream: the empty streetscapes, the shrieking ambulances, the sudden scramble to find toilet paper and hand sanitizer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Steve Lawrence, Who Sang His Listeners Down Memory Lane, Dies at 88
description: With his wife, Eydie Gorme, and sometimes on his own, he kept pop standards in vogue long past their prime. He also acted on television and on Broadway.
content: Steve Lawrence, the mellow baritone nightclub, television and recording star who with his wife and partner, the soprano Eydie Gorme, kept pop standards in vogue long past their prime and took America on musical walks down memory lane for a half-century, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Home Care Aides Fight to End 24-Hour Shifts: ‘This Work Is Killing Them’
description: Home health care, among the fastest growing industries in New York and nationwide, is also one of the lowest paying, with often grueling hours.
content: For eight years, Lai Yee Chen worked 24-hour shifts, up to five days a week, as a home care aide for bed-bound seniors in New York City. She cooked, cleaned, changed diapers and turned her patients at least every two hours to prevent bedsores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: How ‘MagaBabe’ and a Fake Investor Targeted Critics of Viktor Orban
description: A covert campaign to entrap and discredit people linked to rights groups in Hungary has added fuel to longstanding complaints of democratic backsliding in the country.
content: Kati Marton, a Hungarian-born American writer, thought she was talking with a friend of Gen. Wesley Clark, NATO’s former commander in Europe. The man, who had sent her a résumé describing himself as a “results-oriented wealth and investment manager” living in Switzerland, said he was exploring green energy opportunities in Eastern Europe.

title: Dog Sledder Penalized for Poor Moose Gutting
description: While mushing across Alaska in the Iditarod sled dog race, Dallas Seavey shot a moose, and then got a penalty for not gutting it well enough.
content: It’s been a tough Iditarod sled dog race for the five-time winner Dallas Seavey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Duke Asks Its Crazed Basketball Fans to Heckle Responsibly
description: As part of a D.E.I. initiative, the student government held a town hall with fans who are known for their biting intel about opposing players.
content: The fervent basketball fans at Duke University, hundreds of whom are camping in a tent village to get prime seats for Saturday’s rivalry game against the University of North Carolina, have been a target of diversity, equity and inclusion efforts this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Friday Briefing: A New Plan for Gaza Aid
description: Also, President Biden’s annual address and Oscar predictions.
content: President Biden is expected to announce during his State of the Union address that the U.S. military will build a floating pier off Gaza to let ships deliver food and other aid to Gazans, U.S. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: A Journalist Who Moves Between Writing and Recording
description: In an interview, the reporter Annie Correal discussed why she was “thinking for audio” during a recent assignment in South America.
content: For many African migrants, El Dorado International Airport in Bogotá, Colombia, is now one stop on the long journey to the United States. Which is why Annie Correal, who spent January and February covering the Andes region for The New York Times, made the airport a recent reporting destination.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s How to Watch the State of the Union Address
description: In a speech scheduled for 9 p.m., President Biden is set to lay out his agenda directly to the American people. The New York Times will carry the address live.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: A Prayer App Turns to TikTok to Find Its Flock
description: Ads for Hallow, with its pitchman Mark Wahlberg, are reaching nonreligious social media users, much to their surprise.
content: Jon Schneider was mindlessly scrolling TikTok when a video caught his eye. It showed the actor Mark Wahlberg and “this guy who kind of looks like Jesus,” and they were inviting viewers to join them in prayer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Mike Isaac
title: Big American Tech Profits From Chinese Ad Spending Spree
description: Temu, Shein, and streaming and gaming apps looking to break into the U.S. market are spending huge sums to get their wares in front of American consumers.
content: The trade relationship between China and the United States has plenty of friction. But at least one area is booming: Chinese start-ups looking to establish a presence in the West are spending billions of dollars for advertisements on services owned by some of Silicon Valley’s biggest technology companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Opposition Blasts Macron for Risking Escalation in Ukraine
description: The French president attempted to forge a united front on a harder line against Russia. But few were persuaded.
content: Attacked at home and abroad for his statement last month that sending troops to Ukraine “should not be ruled out,” President Emmanuel Macron faced a torrent of outrage from the left and right on Thursday when he met with leaders of major political parties to hammer home his new position.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: String of Islands
description: Joe O’Neill makes a poetic debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Zelensky Names Ukraine’s Ex-Top General Ambassador to U.K.
description: The former top general, Valery Zaluzhny, was dismissed last month amid tensions with the civilian leadership. He has been a very popular figure in Ukraine.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Thursday appointed Valery Zaluzhny as his new ambassador to Britain, just a month after he removed him from his post as the country’s top general amid tensions between the military and civilian leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aidan Gardiner
title: The Shelters Keeping People Out of Shelters
description: Some homeless shelters now offer resources so that people can squeeze in with family members. It’s an acknowledgment that entering the shelter system can lead to a downward spiral.
content: Every day, people go to homeless shelters as a place of last resort. But some shelters, like the Marshall House in Hartford, Conn., are trying to help by turning people away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Nico Grant
title: Ex-Google Engineer Charged With Stealing A.I. Secrets for Chinese Firm
description: Linwei Ding, a Chinese national, was arrested in California and accused of uploading hundreds of files to the cloud.
content: A Chinese citizen who recently quit his job as a software engineer for Google in California has been charged with trying to transfer artificial intelligence technology to a Beijing-based company that paid him secretly, according to a federal indictment unsealed on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Brooke
title: Taylor Tomlinson Is the Perfect Late-Night Host for The TikTok Era
description: ‘After Midnight’ is not a conventional late-night show with monologue, desk and A-list guests. But that may be a good thing.
content: If you picture a modern late-night show, you’ll probably envision a heavy, glossy desk next to an armchair or a couch, with an artificial city vista twinkling behind them. A man, most likely a white man, dressed in a dark suit. Maybe a button-down with the sleeves casually rolled up, if that man’s name is Seth Meyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: 3 Degrees of Trumpiness: Ohio’s Republican Senate Candidates Clash
description: Donald Trump’s choice for the nomination, Bernie Moreno, has eagerly showed off his endorsement, but his two rivals have also embraced the former president or his policies.
content: Three Republicans seeking to take on Senator Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio, in the fall took shots at one another during a debate on Wednesday night as they tried to present themselves as the most conservative candidate in a tightly contested primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Space: The Longest Goodbye’ Review: Alone Up There
description: This documentary by Ido Mizrahy examines the psychological challenges of space exploration for astronauts and their loved ones as scientists consider whether humans could reach Mars.
content: In “Space: The Longest Goodbye,” scientists researching the problems of long-term space exploration go where movies have gone before. Sending astronauts into hibernation to conserve scarce resources? Pairing them with an artificially intelligent entity that can act as a pal and sounding board? Screenwriters have tried these things already, with results probably best kept in fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alicia Napierkowski
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are a two-bedroom in Pound Ridge, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Ridgefield, Conn.
content: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,805-square-foot home built in 1940, with a living room that has a lavish stone fireplace and floor-to-ceiling windows, a kitchen with a breakfast nook, a cozy formal dining room, a bright family room with bay windows facing the yard, a basement with a gym, a breezeway to a two-car heated garage, a large bluestone patio, a built-in firepit, a heated in-ground gunite pool and a large converted barn with living space, on 2.36 acres. Bonnie Stein, Julia B Fee Sotheby’s International Realty, 914-262-0915, williampitt.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Rents Are Flat — or Up, or Down, Depending Where You Look
description: Nationally, one-year rent increases have leveled out, but local conditions may vary.
content: On the national level, rental rates have flattened over the past year — which is good news following the head-spinning increases of 2022 into 2023. But as Zumper’s February rent report points out, how much a renter should expect to pay in 2024 is highly dependent on where they live, with a record amount of new inventory in Western and Southwestern regions offset by low-supplied markets in the Midwest and Northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ray Mark Rinaldi
title: Those Lines on the Wall Are More Than Just Scrawls and Squiggles
description: The artist Shantell Martin sees her trademark line drawings as a meditation of sorts on the meaning of life.
content: For the artist Shantell Martin, every surface has a story. It is just a matter of figuring out how to tell it best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Marks
title: Bond of Brothers: The Black Crowes Are Back, and Bygones Are Bygones
description: After ego clashes and substance abuse drove Chris and Rich Robinson apart, they’ve reunited for their first album of raw rock ’n’ roll together in 15 years.
content: If there’s one thing the fractious Black Crowes co-founders agree on, it’s that they’ve never fit in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Imogen West-Knights
title: Playing a British Rogue, With Added Firepower
description: Daniel Ings has built a career playing charming, posh men. His latest role is a chaotic aristocrat in Guy Ritchie’s series “The Gentlemen.”
content: In the first episode of Guy Ritchie’s new Netflix series “The Gentlemen,” a British aristocrat is forced to dress up in a chicken suit and dance on camera at the pleasure of a gangster to whom he owes money. He flaps his arms wildly, thrusts his head forward and crows at the top of his voice, as tears stream down his face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Breakfast Pasta for Dinner (or Dinner Pasta for Breakfast)
description: Ali Slagle’s new carbonara-leaning skillet pasta with bacon and eggs is a quick and easy meal for any time of day.
content: When I’m tired and hungry and there’s nothing promising in the fridge save for a half-dozen eggs, there’s always breakfast for dinner. Scrambled eggs on toast or a crisper-clearing frittata are dependable, self-assuring standbys. And if I also have a couple of strips of bacon, a generous scoop of orzo and a bit of Parmesan, there’s skillet pasta with bacon and eggs, a brilliant new recipe from Ali Slagle. It’s quick, easy and a little luxe — the runny egg yolks mingle with the bacony, cheesy pasta to create a carbonara-leaning one-pot meal. Eat this for Friday dinner with a handful of arugula on the side (for “health”), or for Sunday breakfast with sliced oranges and never-ending coffee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Go Behind the Scenes of All 10 Best Picture Oscar Nominees’
description: Directors walk viewers through pivotal scenes from their Academy Award-nominated films. What does it take to create a Best Picture nominee?
content: The 96th Academy Awards will be presented on Sunday in Hollywood, celebrating the artistry and achievements of the film industry. Will you be watching?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diana Budds
title: In Furniture, Marks of Distinction That Were Formerly Known as Flaws
description: How design is celebrating an aesthetic of imperfection.
content: The stackable, three-legged Stool 60 is one of the Finnish brand Artek’s most recognizable pieces. But in September, the company released a twist on the classic Alvar Aalto design: stools with knotholes, insect trails and more visible wood grain — elements that are usually considered imperfections. Artek calls them “features.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Tonight’s State of the Union Is a Big Moment for Biden
description: Also, a plan to help get aid into Gaza. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: At about 9 p.m., Eastern, President Biden will stand at the lectern on the floor of the House of Representatives and deliver his State of the Union address. The speech will offer Biden perhaps his best opportunity before Election Day to tell Americans at length about his record in office and what he would do if re-elected.
source.name: The New York Times

description: What President Biden needs to accomplish at Thursday’s State of the Union address.
content: Enough already: It is time to unleash Dark Brandon on this soul-sucking downer of a presidential race. And the most obvious place to begin is to invite him to the State of the Union address.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Is Hungary a Model for Trump?
description: We examine Donald Trump’s affinity for Viktor Orban, Hungary’s prime minister.
content: Tomorrow in Florida, Donald Trump will host Viktor Orban, the prime minister of Hungary, whom Trump often praises. “He is a very great leader, a very strong man,” Trump has said. “Some people don’t like him because he’s too strong.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Top Senators Urge Stores to Stop Selling Illicit Vapes
description: Lawmakers want shopkeepers to remove e-cigarettes that were not authorized by the F.D.A. Retailers say it is not that simple.
content: The chairmen of five key Senate committees on Thursday warned the chief executives of major convenience stores and wholesalers to stop sales of illicit flavored vaping products that they called “widespread violations of federal law.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: This week’s properties are in Harlem, Chelsea and Clinton Hill.
content: A one-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath, 900-square-foot garden-level duplex with a large foyer, an eat-in kitchen with an integrated dishwasher, a full bathroom, a bedroom and a balcony on the first level; and a living area, office nooks, a half bath, a washer and a vented dryer hookup on the lower level; plus a private backyard, ample storage and mini-split heating and air-conditioning, in a five-story prewar building with a virtual intercom. Laura Cook, Keller Williams NYC 917-935-8140; kwnyc.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: You Can’t Beat Beauty and Elegance
description: In advance of the Oscars, here are seven stars (in some of their best looks) who’ve made the case for glamour this awards season.
content: The lead-up to the Oscars is not only for predictions. It’s also an opportunity to take a look back at the style trends that the awards season grind has unearthed. It’s also an opportunity to see celebrities show up week after week in gowns, accessories and regalia, topping their last look, or at least complementing it. We’ve clocked hundreds of looks already in just two short months, some with a lot of oomph and personality, some that left us scratching our heads. But the stars in this round up stood out for their repeatedly refined elegance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen, Vjosa Isai and Isabel Harder
title: 4 Children and 2 Adults Are Killed in Ottawa Home
description: The police are investigating the circumstances surrounding the killings on Wednesday of a Sri Lankan family, the city’s largest mass murder in at least 30 years.
content: A woman from Sri Lanka and her four children were stabbed to death in a home in Ottawa by a student who is also from Sri Lanka, the police said on Thursday. Another man living in the home was also killed, and the children’s father was hospitalized with injuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Passes Migrant Detention Bill, Denouncing Biden Border Policies
description: Thirty-seven Democrats joined Republicans in support of the legislation, which has little chance of enactment but offered the G.O.P. a chance to attack President Biden and Democrats on immigration.
content: The House passed legislation on Thursday that would mandate that migrants who enter the country without authorization and are accused of theft be taken into federal custody, as Republicans pushed a messaging bill to attack President Biden and Democrats as dangerously lax on border enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: The 20 Guests Who Will Sit With Jill Biden at the State of the Union
description: Among the attendees will be the prime minister of Sweden and women who were denied an abortion and in vitro fertilization.
content: Follow live updates on Biden’s State of the Union address.

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Mike Tyson to Fight Jake Paul in Match on Netflix
description: The July bout between Mr. Tyson, the former world champion, and Mr. Paul, the influencer turned boxer, is part of Netflix’s push into “sports-adjacent” live events.
content: At age 58, Mike Tyson will be getting back in the boxing ring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: New York City’s New Power Lunch Restaurants
description: Ladies who lunch, rejoice.
content: Back in 2016, shortly after I joined the magazine Bon Appétit as an assistant editor, two of the top editors treated me to lunch. They decided on Augustine, the short-lived, four-dollar-sign Keith McNally restaurant on the ground floor of the Beekman hotel in the financial district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Ronny Chieng Is Sad to See Nikki Haley Go
description: “The Daily Show” guest host bemoaned that Haley dropped out after President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump crushed Super Tuesday “like it was an audition for a Life Alert commercial.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: New York Community Bank Tries to Reassure Markets After $1 Billion Rescue
description: Management told investors that deposits had fallen, but the bank’s shares jumped on the details of a shift in strategy and large cash infusion led by the former Treasury secretary Steven Mnuchin.
content: A new management team at New York Community Bank is working to reassure investors after the struggling lender announced a $1 billion cash infusion led by the former Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. On Thursday, the bank’s beaten-down shares jumped after executives gave investors new information about the state of the company and details about its rescue plan announced the day before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Michael D. Shear and Thomas Fuller
title: U.S. Military to Build Floating Pier to Ferry Gaza Aid, White House Says
description: U.S. officials said that a temporary port, built from ships and then moved close to shore, would allow hundreds of truckloads of aid to reach Gazans on the brink of starvation.
content: Facing warnings that the war-ravaged Gaza Strip is on the precipice of widespread famine, the United States on Thursday announced plans for a large-scale, amphibious military operation in the Mediterranean Sea that would ferry food and other aid to desperate civilians in the enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Monika Pronczuk
title: Aid From José Andrés’s World Central Kitchen Could Depart for Gaza Within Days, Officials Say
description: The organization founded by the celebrity Spanish chef has served more than 32 million meals in Gaza, and he hopes to do more.
content: The first sea shipment of humanitarian relief to Gaza — food aid from the World Central Kitchen aid agency — could depart the Mediterranean island nation of Cyprus by Saturday, weather permitting, Cypriot officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: James Crumbley Had Chances to Stop Son’s School Shooting, Prosecutors Say
description: The father missed cries for help and failed to secure the gun his son used in a deadly rampage in a Michigan high school, prosecutors said. The defense said he “did not know what his son was planning.”
content: Prosecutors in Michigan on Thursday accused James Crumbley of failing to secure the gun that his son used to open fire in a high school hallway and kill four students — one of several ways they say he could have stopped the deadliest school shooting in state history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta and Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Weirdly Warm Winter Has Climate Fingerprints All Over It, Study Says
description: Recent heat waves in cities worldwide have the hallmarks of global warming, researchers said. And last month was the hottest February on record.
content: Winter was weirdly warm for half the world’s population, driven in many places by the burning of fossil fuels, according to an analysis of temperature data from hundreds of locations worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: When It Comes to Memoirs, Divorce Is All the Rage
description: Lyz Lenz’s memoir, “This American Ex-Wife,” is one of several best-selling autobiographies that lift the veil on imperfect marriages.
content: This is the year of the dragon, the election — and the best-selling marriage memoir, if you subscribe to the idea that three’s a trend. First there was “More,” Molly Roden Winter’s tale of polyamory, which landed on the nonfiction list in February. Then the romantic tide turned, with two accounts of divorce amicably occupying last week’s No. 7 and No. 9 spots. Tempting as it might be to pit their authors, Leslie Jamison and Lyz Lenz — both mothers in their early 40s — against each other, resist the urge. We’re better than that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Met Opera’s Orchestra Will Tour Asia for the First Time
description: After the pandemic forced the cancellation of a tour planned for 2022, the ensemble will visit Japan, South Korea and Taiwan in June.
content: The coronavirus pandemic forced the Metropolitan Opera to shut its doors for more than a year and a half. It also upended plans that had been in the works for the Met Orchestra’s first Asian tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Benjamin Mullin
title: Jay Powell Signals a Retreat on Banking Rules
description: The Fed chair said regulators could scale back or rework a sweeping capital-requirements proposal that Wall Street has been fighting for months.
content: For months, Wall Street C.E.O.s have been complaining bitterly and lobbying against the prospect of higher capital requirements, which would require them to keep more money on hand and would lower their profits. It appears they have scored a big win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Love Lies Bleeding’ Review: Kristen Stewart, Crazy (and Scary) in Love
description: In this neo-noir, the ever reliable, always watchable actress plays a small-town loner who’s struck by the unexpected arrival of a mysterious drifter.
content: Watching Kristen Stewart is always an adventure. A performer who makes good movies better and dreary movies tolerable, she has a restlessness that has made her one of the more interesting attractions in American film. She has a gift for making a character’s inner life transparently readable, and while she can be subtle and withholding, it is her fascinatingly unquiet presence that draws you in, an itchy intensity that can keep her (and you) on edge. Pauline Kael wrote that Jane Fonda’s “motor runs a little fast” — so does Stewart’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley, Hurubie Meko and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: How Bad Is Crime in the Subways?
description: Officials have spent millions to make New Yorkers transit riders feel safe. The investment is motivated more by passengers’ perception than by crime rates.

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Approves Expansion of Fund for Nuclear Waste Exposure Victims
description: Senators estimate the measure would provide as much as $40 billion in compensation, extending and substantially broadening a benefit that had been scheduled to expire in June.
content: The Senate on Thursday passed bipartisan legislation that would significantly expand a law allowing victims of government-caused nuclear contamination who developed cancer and other serious illnesses to receive federal compensation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delthia Ricks
title: Dr. Anthony Epstein, Pathologist Who Discovered Epstein-Barr Virus, Dies at 102
description: His groundbreaking research, which he performed with Yvonne Barr, his doctoral student, uncovered the first virus capable of causing cancer in humans.
content: In March 1961, Dr. Anthony Epstein, a pathologist at Middlesex Hospital in London, almost skipped a visiting physician’s afternoon lecture about children with exceptionally large facial tumors in Uganda.

title: Why California Hasn’t Ditched Daylight Saving Time

content: President Biden and former President Trump are worlds apart on climate policy. But do voters know it?

content: How do you take a complex and nuanced New York Times article, video, podcast, graph or photo essay and turn its information and ideas into an accessible and engaging visual guide for readers? That’s what we challenged students to do in our Second Annual One-Pager Challenge.

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Eight Teens Are Shot at Philadelphia Bus Stop, Police Say
description: The injured high school students, one of whom was in critical condition, range in age from 15 to 17, the police said. It was the latest in a series of shootings on or near public buses in the city.
content: Eight Philadelphia high school students were shot and wounded as they waited for a public bus after school on Wednesday, the latest in a spate of shootings that have touched off outrage in the city, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Richard Truly, 86, Dies; Shuttle Astronaut Who Went On to Lead NASA
description: In 1983, he commanded a Challenger shuttle flight. After the 1986 disaster, he was charged with leading NASA’s return to space.
content: Richard Truly, a naval aviator and astronaut who flew aboard two early space shuttle missions and, as NASA’s associate administrator, guided the agency’s return to space after the Challenger disaster, died on Feb. 27 at his home in Genesee, Colo. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg and Stacy Cowley
title: Judge Blocks Debt Settlement Company From Resuming Operations
description: Strategic Financial Solutions is accused of fraud in a lawsuit by federal and state prosecutors.
content: The federal government is likely to win in its lawsuit against Strategic Financial Solutions, a debt negotiation company covered in a Times investigation last month, according to a magistrate judge’s preliminary injunction granted this week that keeps it from operating.

author: By James Barron
title: A Fire Dept. Chaplain Breaking Barriers
description: The Rev. Pamela Holmes will be sworn in today as the Fire Department’s second female chaplain, and the first Black woman in the role.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll meet the New York Fire Department’s newest chaplain. We’ll also get details on Gov. Kathy Hochul’s decision to send State Police and National Guard soldiers into the New York City subway system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gulley and Catrin Einhorn
title: How to Move a 1,000-Pound Rescued Manatee (Swimming Isn’t an Option)
description: Three orphaned calves were found in Florida. Then they racked up the frequent flyer miles.
content: The orphans, three baby females, arrived one after the other at ZooTampa’s manatee hospital.

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Neighbor May Be a Hoarder. How Do We Get in There and Find Out?
description: Respecting your neighbor’s privacy is a friendly instinct. But you might have to get aggressive to ensure everyone else’s well-being.
content: Q: I am on the board of a small co-op in Manhattan. One of our residents is very private, and possibly a hoarder. He refuses to allow anyone to enter his apartment, even the super. The managing agent has tried contacting this resident by phone and by letter so he can investigate a foul smell that is likely coming from the apartment, but the resident does not respond. The resident’s family member who has helped us in the past has been unreachable. How do we respect this person’s privacy while also making sure that his apartment isn’t disturbing others?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Baseball Video Game Will Include Women for the First Time
description: MLB The Show 24 will feature a career mode that allows gamers to create a female player and steer her journey to the big leagues. The game draws on the experiences of female baseball players.
content: For the first time, women will don Major League Baseball jerseys in MLB The Show, the long-running popular video game.

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: Trump’s Super Tuesday Speech: Assessing 10 False and Misleading Claims
description: After racking up a series of wins that cleared the field, former President Donald J. Trump moved to a general election message. Here’s a fact check.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump moved another step closer to becoming the 2024 Republican nominee for president Tuesday, sweeping up delegates and prompting his last remaining rival, Nikki Haley, to suspend her campaign. The results all but guarantee a November rematch against President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Keepnews
title: What’s the Greatest Jazz Record? Here’s a Clue: Miles Davis.
description: James Kaplan’s new book, “3 Shades of Blue,” examines the lives of Miles, John Coltrane and Bill Evans, and the extraordinary album they made.
content: Miles Davis was one of the biggest stars in jazz as well as one of the most innovative and influential musicians. John Coltrane was both a saxophone virtuoso and a fearless explorer whose lifelong musical and spiritual quest attracted a passionate following — and later, as that quest went beyond the boundaries of jazz as many people understood the word, heated criticism. Bill Evans redefined the concept of the piano trio and rewrote the rules of jazz harmony. And on one memorable occasion in 1959, all three participated in the creation of what many consider the greatest jazz record ever made, Davis’s “Kind of Blue.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: A New Book Fills In the Human Stories Behind Unmarked Graves
description: In “The Unclaimed,” the sociologists Pamela Prickett and Stefan Timmermans tell four stories of dying alone — and living — in America.
content: In October 2001, the playwright Leonard Melfi, known for his prolific work in experimental theater, died alone at 68 in a Manhattan hospital, ending a long alcoholic decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Thursday Briefing
description: Nikki Haley ends her presidential campaign.
content: Nikki Haley announced yesterday that she was ending her presidential campaign, clearing the way for another general election contest between President Biden and former President Donald Trump, an outcome many Americans had hoped to avoid. She had come to represent the last, best chance for Republicans hoping to turn the page on Trump’s divisive brand of politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury
title: Should Either of These People Have the Power to End the World?
description: The president’s sole authority to use nuclear weapons needs to be re-examined in today’s world.
content: A large majority of Americans say they don’t trust a government run by the opposition party. So we must ask ourselves: Is it moral, just and wise to vest the ability to end other nations in the hands of one person?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Kennedy
title: Lucas Samaras, Artist Who Was His Own Canvas, Dies at 87
description: A wild card even by the rabble-rousing standards of the 1960s, he once said that he used himself in his art “because it is still unorthodox to use one’s self.”
content: Lucas Samaras, who sang the song of self louder and in more keys than perhaps any other postwar visual artist, creating a wildly diverse body of work in which his own lithe body, bearded face and personal effects took center stage in countless shape-shifting guises, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

content: In January, Newark, N.J., voted to allow 16- and 17-year-olds to vote in local school board races. Supporters hoped that the ordinance would mark the start of a statewide and national movement. Critics said teenagers were “not ready to make these decisions.”

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘Glitter & Doom’ Review: As a Vibe, It’s Fun. As a Film? Closer to Fine.
description: Songs by the Indigo Girls soundtrack a musical romance.
content: There’s nostalgic art. Then there’s art that seems like somebody thawed it after 30 frozen years. “Glitter & Doom” doesn’t yearn for some older time. It’s pure time-warp: a gay musical-love-dramedy that could’ve screened all summer at the old Philadelphia art house where I used to work, plunked amid the queer independent-filmmaking bonanza that helped make the early-to-mid-1990s seem like every gay thing was possible. The movie’s got an earnest, amateurish case of the feel-good gosh-gollies that would have made sense playing down the hall from movies as different (although not that different) as “Go Fish” and “Wigstock,” “Zero Patience” and “The Incredibly True Adventure of Two Girls in Love” and — God help us all — “Claire of the Moon.” The two dozen or so songs in “Glitter & Doom” aren’t new (but aren’t based on Tom Waits’s 15-year-old live album, either). They’re by the Indigo Girls. Many of them are songs the Indigo Girls made a certain kind of popular during the years of that very bonanza. And what the movie does with them is call attention to the emotional mountain range of Emily Saliers and Amy Ray’s songwriting.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Ever since a real, live bullet discharged from the gun that Alec Baldwin was rehearsing with on the set of the film “Rust” in 2021, killing the cinematographer and wounding the director, one question has vexed everyone involved: How did live ammunition end up on a film set, where — all agree — it absolutely should never have been?

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘High & Low — John Galliano’ Review: Designing a Comeback
description: This documentary tracks what happened after the British designer was caught on camera voicing racist and antisemitic hate speech.
content: By the time the documentary “High & Low: John Galliano” enters its second hour, you have learned a little about its titular subject’s life. You’ve seen him at work and at play, and you’ve also watched his 2011 drunken antisemitic rant — “I love Hitler” — which was captured on video. You’ve learned about his childhood in England, his time studying fashion in school, his habit of indulging to excess. Mostly, you have witnessed the unfolding of one of the most exalted careers in high fashion, a decades-long spectacle filled with sensational designs, leggy beauties and air kisses, all set to the drone of millions upon millions of dollars in annual sales.

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: It Was Like the Vigor Had Suddenly Been Sucked Out of His Body. What Was It?
description: The 70-year-old man rapidly went from walking 10 to 15 miles a day to being nearly helpless. His wife wondered if he’d had a stroke.
content: Surrounded by the detritus of a Thanksgiving dinner, the woman was loading the dishwasher when a loud thump thundered through the house. She hurried out of the kitchen to find her husband of 37 years sitting on the second-floor landing. Her son and son-in-law, an emergency-room doctor, crouched at his side. Her husband protested that he was fine, then began to scooch himself on his bottom into the bedroom. The two young men helped him to his feet. The man’s body shook with a wild tremor that nearly knocked him down again. “I was getting into bed and fell,” he explained — though the bed was too far away to make this at all likely. “Get some sleep,” the woman said gently once her husband was settled in the bed. “We’ll go to the hospital in the morning.”

title: TikTok Prompts Users to Call Congress to Fight Possible Ban

title: Hundreds Are Feared Seized in Nigeria, as Kidnapping Epidemic Worsens

content: Theirs were already lives of great hardship, in camps for displaced people, after they had fled their homes in Nigeria’s embattled northeast. One recent day, they risked a foray into the countryside to collect firewood — and around 200 of them, some officials said, were kidnapped.

content: Have you tried numerous avenues to help your chronic illness, obesity or mental health and turned to Ozempic, Wegovy or another GLP-1 drug to address these issues? content: Unlike many designers, much of the work of the costume designer Ellen Mirojnick is contemporary. Her filmography is evidence of the impact she has had on the look and feel of some of the most iconic films of the 1980s and ’90s: Paul Verhoeven’s “Basic Instinct” (1992) and “Showgirls” (1995), Adrian Lyne’s “Fatal Attraction” (1987) and “Unfaithful” (2002), and Andrew Davis’s “A Perfect Murder” (1998).
